DOC.HEAD: Six Hurt, High-Rise Evacuated in Construction Site Fire
Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with two more firefighters injured, San Diego high-rise fire; pick up 5th graf, `Four hundred ...'; ADDS 2 grafs at end with details on San Diego fire. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A raging pre-dawn fire chased 106 residents from a 14-story condominium, burned two construction sites and set the roofs of five expensive homes ablaze before it was doused early Saturday. Seven firefighters suffered minor injuries and an 89-year-old woman was hospitalized for smoke inhalation. All were in good condition, said Fire Chief Donald Manning. A fire also broke out Saturday morning on the top floor of a 15-story apartment building in San Diego. Six people were hospitalized with minor injuries and dozens were evacuated. The Los Angeles fire broke out around 3:30 a.m. in a four-story apartment building that was in the final stages of construction, and spread to the condominium tower and to a three-story apartment building. It hopped Wilshire Boulevard and ignited chemical drums at a construction site and residential roofs downwind. The cause was unknown but arson teams were investigating, Manning said. Four hundred firefighters battled the blaze in the neighborhood between the exclusive Los Angeles Country Club and the University of California, Los Angeles. Firefighters had to battle thick smoke and extreme heat to evacuate the apartment building's residents. ``The smoke and the heat are so bad that firefighters are going in to look for people on their hands and knees,'' said Sgt. Gene Allen of the UCLA Police Department. Everyone was accounted for by late morning, said Fire Department spokesman Ed Reed. Many of those evacuated were people in wheelchairs, Allen said. A damage estimate was not immediately available, but losses were expected to be in the millions. Some residents said a sound resembling an explosion preceded the outbreak of the fire. In San Diego, fire broke out around 8:30 a.m. in a 15th-floor apartment and flames and heavy smoke spread to the 13th and 14th floors, said a city fire dispatcher who declined to give her name. Firefighters contained the three-alarm blaze within an hour, the fire dispatcher said. It was not known exactly how many people were evacuated. Damage to the building was estimated at $300,000.
